cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
what does sip stand for in the ngn / ims context
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
In the context of Next Generation Networks (NGN) and IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), "SIP" stands for Session Initiation Protocol. SIP is a signaling protocol used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time sessions that involve video, voice, messaging, and other communications applications. It is a fundamental component of IMS architecture, enabling the establishment of multimedia sessions over IP networks.

Answer: SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol in the NGN/IMS context.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
what does sip stand for in the ngn / ims context
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['SIP or sip may refer to:\n', 'The NG9-1-1 vision relies on 9-1-1 specific application functionality on an Emergency Services IP Network (ESInet) to deliver voice, video, text and data "calls" to the PSAP. The protocol used for delivering these "calls" will be the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), or IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS, which incorporates SIP). The functional and interface standards developed by NENA describe general SIP and IMS-based architectures that allow responsible 9-1-1 Authorities flexibility in developing an infrastructure to support the envisioned features of NG9-1-1.\n', 'The IDP receives a message (IDP Message) initiated by the SSP (service switching point) and transmitted to the service control point SCP via the INAP protocol. The Service Switching Point (SSP) receives a message "(ISUP Message)" initiated by the Calling Party, this could be an IAM (Initial Address Message). The SSP evaluates the nature of the message, in the case of the IAM the called and calling party numbers. From this it determines whether it can route the call or whether it needs further instructions. In this case if the SSP does require further instructions it sends an IDP to a service control point SCP via an IN protocol. The protocol may be INAP but could be CAMEL, or bespoke INAP flavours such as Ericsson INAP, Nokia INAP, Siemens INAP\n', 'BULLET::::- Source normalized impact per paper (SNIP) – a factor released in 2012 by Elsevier based on Scopus to estimate impact. The measure is calculated as SNIP=RIP/(R/M), where RIP=raw impact per paper, R = citation potential and M = median database citation potential.\n', 'SIP was designed to provide a signaling and call setup protocol for IP-based communications supporting the call processing functions and features present in the public switched telephone network (PSTN) with a vision of supporting new multimedia applications. It has been extended for video conferencing, streaming media distribution, instant messaging, presence information, file transfer, Internet fax and online games.\n', "The abbreviation P.I.S. means piss in Danish, which should be a dead give-away about the nature of the show. The style of the show, however, convinced many people that it was a documentary, and that the abbreviation was just an unfortunate, but real, occurrence. Other Danish police and army institutions sound peculiar in Danish, when abbreviated, such as the Danish Defence Intelligence Service (da: Forsvarets Efterretningstjeneste - FE) sounding like the Danish word for fairy, or the police equivalent (PET), hence P.I.S. wasn't too far off.\n", 'SIP-I, or the Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP, is a protocol used to create, modify, and terminate communication sessions based on ISUP using SIP and IP networks. Services using SIP-I include voice, video telephony, fax and data. SIP-I and SIP-T are two protocols with similar features, notably to allow ISUP messages to be transported over SIP networks. This preserves all of the detail available in the ISUP header, which is important as there are many country-specific variants of ISUP that have been implemented over the last 30 years, and it is not always possible to express all of the same detail using a native SIP message. SIP-I was defined by the ITU-T, whereas SIP-T was defined via the IETF RFC route.\n', 'The Soft Input Panel (also called S.I.P.) is a special on-screen input method for devices which do not have standard keyboards. SIP is commonly used in Microsoft Pocket PC and Tablet PC devices, where there is no room for a keyboard. In Microsoft Windows there is a similar on-screen keyboard used as a Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) which also has an ability to change its layout according to current keyboard language and key layout. It was patented by Microsoft in November 2004 under the patent number 6819315.\n', 'In competition law, before deciding whether companies have significant market power which would justify government intervention, the test of small but significant and non-transitory increase in price (SSNIP) is used to define the relevant market in a consistent way. It is an alternative to ad hoc determination of the relevant market by arguments about product similarity.\n', 'The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is the signaling protocol selected by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) to create and control multimedia sessions with two or more participants in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), and therefore is a key element in the IMS framework.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding what "SIP" stands for in the context of NGN (Next Generation Networks) and IMS (IP Multimedia Subsystem), we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content

1. **Definition of SIP**:
   - "SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol, which is a signaling protocol used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time sessions that involve video, voice, messaging, and other communications applications."

2. **Role of SIP in NGN/IMS**:
   - "The NG9-1-1 vision relies on 9-1-1 specific application functionality on an Emergency Services IP Network (ESInet) to deliver voice, video, text and data 'calls' to the PSAP. The protocol used for delivering these 'calls' will be the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), or IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS, which incorporates SIP)."
   - "SIP was designed to provide a signaling and call setup protocol for IP-based communications supporting the call processing functions and features present in the public switched telephone network (PSTN) with a vision of supporting new multimedia applications."

3. **SIP's Applications**:
   - "SIP has been extended for video conferencing, streaming media distribution, instant messaging, presence information, file transfer, Internet fax, and online games."
   - "SIP-I, or the Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP, is a protocol used to create, modify, and terminate communication sessions based on ISUP using SIP and IP networks."

4. **SIP in the IMS Framework**:
   - "The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is the signaling protocol selected by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) to create and control multimedia sessions with two or more participants in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), and therefore is a key element in the IMS framework."

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content

1. **Clarification of SIP**: 
   - The definition of SIP as the Session Initiation Protocol is crucial for understanding its role in telecommunications. It highlights that SIP is not just a standalone protocol but is integral to the functioning of modern communication systems, particularly in IP-based networks.

2. **Contextual Importance**:
   - The passages explain how SIP is utilized within the framework of NGN and IMS, emphasizing its importance in emergency services (like NG9-1-1) and multimedia communications. This context helps clarify why SIP is significant in these advanced network architectures.

3. **Broad Applications**:
   - By outlining the various applications of SIP (e.g., video conferencing, instant messaging), the passages illustrate its versatility and relevance in contemporary communication technologies. This understanding is essential for grasping the full scope of SIP's functionality beyond simple voice calls.

4. **Integration with Other Protocols**:
   - The mention of SIP-I and its relationship with ISUP (Integrated Services Digital Network User Part) highlights how SIP can interact with traditional telephony protocols, bridging the gap between legacy systems and modern IP-based communications. This integration is vital for understanding how SIP supports a seamless transition to next-generation networks.

5. **Role in IMS**:
   - The identification of SIP as a key element in the IMS framework underscores its foundational role in enabling multimedia sessions. This knowledge is critical for comprehending how IMS operates and the significance of SIP in facilitating complex communication scenarios.

### Conclusion

The extracted content provides a comprehensive understanding of SIP's definition, applications, and its role within NGN and IMS. This background knowledge is essential for answering questions related to SIP in telecommunications, particularly in the context of modern, IP-based communication systems. By understanding these concepts, one can appreciate the significance of SIP in facilitating diverse communication services and its integration with existing protocols.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the context of Next Generation Networks (NGN) and the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), "SIP" stands for Session Initiation Protocol. This protocol is essential for establishing, maintaining, and terminating real-time communication sessions that can involve various forms of media, including voice, video, and messaging. 

1. **Definition of SIP**: 
   - SIP is a signaling protocol that plays a critical role in modern telecommunications, particularly in IP-based networks. It allows for the setup and management of multimedia sessions, making it a foundational element of the IMS architecture.

2. **Role of SIP in NGN/IMS**: 
   - Within the NGN framework, SIP is utilized to facilitate emergency services communications, such as the NG9-1-1 system, which relies on SIP to deliver voice, video, text, and data calls to Public Safety Answering Points (PSAPs). This highlights SIP's importance in ensuring reliable and efficient emergency communication.

3. **Applications of SIP**: 
   - SIP is versatile and has been extended to support various applications, including video conferencing, instant messaging, and streaming media. This broad applicability underscores its relevance in contemporary communication technologies.

4. **Integration with Other Protocols**: 
   - SIP can work alongside traditional telephony protocols, such as ISUP (Integrated Services Digital Network User Part), through extensions like SIP-I. This capability allows for a smooth transition from legacy systems to modern IP-based infrastructures, ensuring that existing services can be maintained while adopting new technologies.

5. **SIP in the IMS Framework**: 
   - The 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) has selected SIP as the primary signaling protocol for creating and controlling multimedia sessions within the IMS framework. This designation emphasizes SIP's foundational role in enabling complex communication scenarios involving multiple participants.

### Conclusion:
The understanding of SIP as the Session Initiation Protocol is crucial for grasping its significance in NGN and IMS contexts. Its role in facilitating diverse communication services, its integration with existing protocols, and its applications in emergency services and multimedia communications illustrate its importance in modern telecommunications.

### Answer:
SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol in the NGN/IMS context. It is a signaling protocol used to initiate, maintain, and terminate real-time communication sessions involving various media types, and it plays a foundational role in the architecture of IP Multimedia Subsystems.

Task Description:

Carefully extract the most relevant foundational and advanced knowledge from these passages, with a particular focus on how the context of the retrieved information relates to the question. In the context of Next Generation Networks (NGN) and the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), "SIP" stands for **Session Initiation Protocol**. This protocol is fundamental for establishing, managing, and terminating multimedia communication sessions over IP networks. 

### Contextual Insights:

1. **Role in NGN/IMS**: SIP is specifically designed to facilitate signaling and call setup for IP-based communications, which is crucial for supporting various multimedia applications. This includes voice calls, video conferencing, instant messaging, and more. The integration of SIP within the IMS framework allows for the management of multimedia sessions involving multiple participants, making it a key component in modern telecommunications.

2. **Technical Specifications**: The passages indicate that SIP was selected by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) as the signaling protocol for IMS. This highlights its importance in the standardization of communication protocols in next-generation networks, ensuring interoperability and flexibility in developing infrastructure for services like NG9-1-1.

3. **Extensions and Variants**: SIP has been extended to accommodate various communication needs, such as SIP-I (Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP) and SIP-T, which allow for the transport of ISUP messages over SIP networks. This is significant because it preserves the details of traditional telephony signaling while leveraging the advantages of IP networks.

4. **Broader Implications**: The use of SIP in NGN and IMS contexts reflects a shift from traditional Public Switched Telephone Networks (PSTN) to more flexible, IP-based systems. This transition supports a wider range of services and applications, aligning with the evolving needs of users and the telecommunications industry.

### Summary:

In summary, within the NGN and IMS context, SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol. It serves as a critical signaling protocol that enables the establishment and management of multimedia communication sessions over IP networks. Its integration into the IMS framework underscores its significance in modern telecommunications, facilitating a variety of communication services and ensuring compatibility with existing telephony protocols. The evolution and extensions of SIP further illustrate its adaptability and importance in the ongoing development of next-generation communication infrastructures.

Answer:

### Context-enhanced Reasoning Process:

In the context of Next Generation Networks (NGN) and the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), "SIP" stands for **Session Initiation Protocol**. This protocol plays a crucial role in modern telecommunications by enabling the initiation, maintenance, and termination of real-time communication sessions, which can include voice, video, and messaging applications. 

1. **Role in NGN/IMS**: SIP is specifically designed for signaling and call setup in IP-based communications. Its functionality is essential for supporting a wide range of multimedia applications, including voice calls, video conferencing, and instant messaging. The integration of SIP within the IMS framework allows for the management of complex multimedia sessions that can involve multiple participants, highlighting its significance in facilitating modern communication.

2. **Technical Specifications**: The selection of SIP by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) as the signaling protocol for IMS underscores its importance in standardizing communication protocols for next-generation networks. This standardization ensures that various services, including emergency services like NG9-1-1, can be developed with interoperability and flexibility in mind.

3. **Extensions and Variants**: SIP has been extended to include variants such as SIP-I (Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP) and SIP-T, which allow for the transport of traditional telephony signaling messages over SIP networks. This capability is significant as it preserves the detailed information contained in ISUP messages, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of communication across different network types.

4. **Broader Implications**: The adoption of SIP in NGN and IMS contexts represents a shift from traditional Public Switched Telephone Networks (PSTN) to more adaptable, IP-based systems. This transition supports a broader array of services and applications, reflecting the evolving needs of users and the telecommunications industry as a whole.

### Final Answer:
In the context of NGN and IMS, SIP stands for **Session Initiation Protocol**. It is a critical signaling protocol that facilitates the establishment and management of multimedia communication sessions over IP networks, playing a vital role in modern telecommunications infrastructure.

   - SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol, which is a signaling protocol used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time sessions that include voice, video, and messaging applications.

2. **Role in NGN/IMS**:
   - SIP is integral to the NG9-1-1 vision, facilitating the delivery of voice, video, text, and data calls over an Emergency Services IP Network (ESInet).
   - It is a key element in the IMS framework, which is designed to support multimedia applications and services.

3. **Functionality**:
   - SIP was designed to replicate call processing functions found in traditional public switched telephone networks (PSTN) while extending capabilities to support new multimedia applications.
   - It allows for the creation, modification, and termination of communication sessions, thus enabling various services such as voice telephony, video conferencing, and instant messaging.

4. **Protocols Related to SIP**:
   - SIP-I (Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP) and SIP-T are protocols that allow ISUP messages to be transported over SIP networks, preserving the details of the ISUP header.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Relationships**:
   - By recognizing that SIP serves as a foundational protocol for multimedia communications in NGN and IMS, the model can better understand the relationships between different communication technologies and their functionalities. This understanding is crucial for making inferences about how changes in one area (e.g., the introduction of new SIP features) might impact overall communication capabilities.

2. **Causal Connections**:
   - The model can infer causal relationships, such as how the implementation of SIP in NG9-1-1 systems enhances emergency response capabilities by enabling diverse communication methods (voice, video, text). This understanding allows the model to predict outcomes based on changes in protocol usage or technology.

3. **Complex Systems Analysis**:
   - The information about SIP's role in both traditional and modern communication systems enables the model to analyze complex systems more effectively. It can reason about how different components (like SIP, ISUP, and IMS) interact and affect each other, leading to a more nuanced understanding of system dynamics.

4. **Scenario Simulation**:
   - With knowledge of SIP's functionalities and its applications, the model can simulate various scenarios (e.g., a failure in SIP leading to communication breakdown) and reason through potential outcomes, enhancing its predictive capabilities.

5. **Adaptation to New Information**:
   - As new protocols or updates to SIP are developed, the model can adapt its reasoning based on the foundational knowledge of how SIP operates within the broader context of NGN and IMS, allowing for continuous improvement in logical inference.

### Conclusion:
The extracted information about SIP in the context of NGN and IMS provides a rich foundation for enhancing the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. By understanding the definitions, roles, functionalities, and interrelations of communication protocols, the model can make more informed predictions, analyze complex systems, and adapt to new developments in technology. This holistic understanding is essential for improving the model's reasoning processes and its ability to draw logical conclusions based on varying scenarios.

It replicates the call processing functions of traditional public switched telephone networks (PSTN) while extending capabilities to support multimedia applications. This means that SIP is not just about making calls; it also enables video conferencing, instant messaging, and other forms of communication.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
what does sip stand for in the ngn / ims context
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['SIP or sip may refer to:\n', 'The NG9-1-1 vision relies on 9-1-1 specific application functionality on an Emergency Services IP Network (ESInet) to deliver voice, video, text and data "calls" to the PSAP. The protocol used for delivering these "calls" will be the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), or IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS, which incorporates SIP). The functional and interface standards developed by NENA describe general SIP and IMS-based architectures that allow responsible 9-1-1 Authorities flexibility in developing an infrastructure to support the envisioned features of NG9-1-1.\n', 'The IDP receives a message (IDP Message) initiated by the SSP (service switching point) and transmitted to the service control point SCP via the INAP protocol. The Service Switching Point (SSP) receives a message "(ISUP Message)" initiated by the Calling Party, this could be an IAM (Initial Address Message). The SSP evaluates the nature of the message, in the case of the IAM the called and calling party numbers. From this it determines whether it can route the call or whether it needs further instructions. In this case if the SSP does require further instructions it sends an IDP to a service control point SCP via an IN protocol. The protocol may be INAP but could be CAMEL, or bespoke INAP flavours such as Ericsson INAP, Nokia INAP, Siemens INAP\n', 'BULLET::::- Source normalized impact per paper (SNIP) – a factor released in 2012 by Elsevier based on Scopus to estimate impact. The measure is calculated as SNIP=RIP/(R/M), where RIP=raw impact per paper, R = citation potential and M = median database citation potential.\n', 'SIP was designed to provide a signaling and call setup protocol for IP-based communications supporting the call processing functions and features present in the public switched telephone network (PSTN) with a vision of supporting new multimedia applications. It has been extended for video conferencing, streaming media distribution, instant messaging, presence information, file transfer, Internet fax and online games.\n', "The abbreviation P.I.S. means piss in Danish, which should be a dead give-away about the nature of the show. The style of the show, however, convinced many people that it was a documentary, and that the abbreviation was just an unfortunate, but real, occurrence. Other Danish police and army institutions sound peculiar in Danish, when abbreviated, such as the Danish Defence Intelligence Service (da: Forsvarets Efterretningstjeneste - FE) sounding like the Danish word for fairy, or the police equivalent (PET), hence P.I.S. wasn't too far off.\n", 'SIP-I, or the Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP, is a protocol used to create, modify, and terminate communication sessions based on ISUP using SIP and IP networks. Services using SIP-I include voice, video telephony, fax and data. SIP-I and SIP-T are two protocols with similar features, notably to allow ISUP messages to be transported over SIP networks. This preserves all of the detail available in the ISUP header, which is important as there are many country-specific variants of ISUP that have been implemented over the last 30 years, and it is not always possible to express all of the same detail using a native SIP message. SIP-I was defined by the ITU-T, whereas SIP-T was defined via the IETF RFC route.\n', 'The Soft Input Panel (also called S.I.P.) is a special on-screen input method for devices which do not have standard keyboards. SIP is commonly used in Microsoft Pocket PC and Tablet PC devices, where there is no room for a keyboard. In Microsoft Windows there is a similar on-screen keyboard used as a Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) which also has an ability to change its layout according to current keyboard language and key layout. It was patented by Microsoft in November 2004 under the patent number 6819315.\n', 'In competition law, before deciding whether companies have significant market power which would justify government intervention, the test of small but significant and non-transitory increase in price (SSNIP) is used to define the relevant market in a consistent way. It is an alternative to ad hoc determination of the relevant market by arguments about product similarity.\n', 'The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is the signaling protocol selected by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) to create and control multimedia sessions with two or more participants in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), and therefore is a key element in the IMS framework.\n']

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

In the context of Next Generation Networks (NGN) and the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), "SIP" stands for Session Initiation Protocol. This protocol is essential for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time communication sessions that involve various media types, including video, voice, and messaging. SIP serves as a signaling protocol that facilitates the establishment of multimedia sessions over IP networks, making it a fundamental component of the IMS architecture.

Additionally, SIP plays a critical role in the implementation of NG9-1-1 (Next Generation 911) systems, where it is utilized to deliver voice, video, text, and data calls to Public Safety Answering Points (PSAPs). This application underscores SIP's importance in emergency services, highlighting its versatility beyond traditional telecommunications.

Furthermore, SIP is recognized as a key element in the IMS framework, as designated by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP). This relationship emphasizes SIP's integral role in the overall architecture of IMS, which is designed to support a wide range of multimedia applications.

SIP has also been extended for various applications, including video conferencing, streaming media, instant messaging, presence information, and file transfer. These extensions illustrate SIP's adaptability and functionality in modern communication scenarios.

Moreover, protocols such as SIP-I (Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP) and SIP-T have been developed to enable the transport of ISUP messages over SIP networks. These protocols preserve the details available in ISUP headers, which is crucial for maintaining compatibility with country-specific ISUP variants.

By integrating this comprehensive understanding of SIP's definition, applications, and extensions, the model can better grasp its significance in NGN and IMS contexts, thereby reducing the likelihood of factual errors and addressing potential model illusions.

**Answer:**
SIP stands for Session Initiation Protocol in the NGN/IMS context. It is a signaling protocol used for initiating, maintaining, and terminating real-time communication sessions involving video, voice, and messaging. SIP is a fundamental component of the IMS architecture and is also utilized in NG9-1-1 systems to deliver various types of calls to Public Safety Answering Points (PSAPs). Additionally, SIP has been extended for applications such as video conferencing and instant messaging, and includes variants like SIP-I and SIP-T for transporting ISUP messages over SIP networks.

question_info.question: what does sip stand for in the ngn / ims context
passages:
SIP or sip may refer to:
The NG9-1-1 vision relies on 9-1-1 specific application functionality on an Emergency Services IP Network (ESInet) to deliver voice, video, text and data "calls" to the PSAP. The protocol used for delivering these "calls" will be the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), or IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS, which incorporates SIP). The functional and interface standards developed by NENA describe general SIP and IMS-based architectures that allow responsible 9-1-1 Authorities flexibility in developing an infrastructure to support the envisioned features of NG9-1-1.
The IDP receives a message (IDP Message) initiated by the SSP (service switching point) and transmitted to the service control point SCP via the INAP protocol. The Service Switching Point (SSP) receives a message "(ISUP Message)" initiated by the Calling Party, this could be an IAM (Initial Address Message). The SSP evaluates the nature of the message, in the case of the IAM the called and calling party numbers. From this it determines whether it can route the call or whether it needs further instructions. In this case if the SSP does require further instructions it sends an IDP to a service control point SCP via an IN protocol. The protocol may be INAP but could be CAMEL, or bespoke INAP flavours such as Ericsson INAP, Nokia INAP, Siemens INAP
BULLET::::- Source normalized impact per paper (SNIP) – a factor released in 2012 by Elsevier based on Scopus to estimate impact. The measure is calculated as SNIP=RIP/(R/M), where RIP=raw impact per paper, R = citation potential and M = median database citation potential.
SIP was designed to provide a signaling and call setup protocol for IP-based communications supporting the call processing functions and features present in the public switched telephone network (PSTN) with a vision of supporting new multimedia applications. It has been extended for video conferencing, streaming media distribution, instant messaging, presence information, file transfer, Internet fax and online games.
The abbreviation P.I.S. means piss in Danish, which should be a dead give-away about the nature of the show. The style of the show, however, convinced many people that it was a documentary, and that the abbreviation was just an unfortunate, but real, occurrence. Other Danish police and army institutions sound peculiar in Danish, when abbreviated, such as the Danish Defence Intelligence Service (da: Forsvarets Efterretningstjeneste - FE) sounding like the Danish word for fairy, or the police equivalent (PET), hence P.I.S. wasn't too far off.
SIP-I, or the Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP, is a protocol used to create, modify, and terminate communication sessions based on ISUP using SIP and IP networks. Services using SIP-I include voice, video telephony, fax and data. SIP-I and SIP-T are two protocols with similar features, notably to allow ISUP messages to be transported over SIP networks. This preserves all of the detail available in the ISUP header, which is important as there are many country-specific variants of ISUP that have been implemented over the last 30 years, and it is not always possible to express all of the same detail using a native SIP message. SIP-I was defined by the ITU-T, whereas SIP-T was defined via the IETF RFC route.
The Soft Input Panel (also called S.I.P.) is a special on-screen input method for devices which do not have standard keyboards. SIP is commonly used in Microsoft Pocket PC and Tablet PC devices, where there is no room for a keyboard. In Microsoft Windows there is a similar on-screen keyboard used as a Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) which also has an ability to change its layout according to current keyboard language and key layout. It was patented by Microsoft in November 2004 under the patent number 6819315.
In competition law, before deciding whether companies have significant market power which would justify government intervention, the test of small but significant and non-transitory increase in price (SSNIP) is used to define the relevant market in a consistent way. It is an alternative to ad hoc determination of the relevant market by arguments about product similarity.
The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is the signaling protocol selected by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) to create and control multimedia sessions with two or more participants in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS), and therefore is a key element in the IMS framework.
